image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives About this object

profileText: (Cousin of Gunning Bedford), a Delegate from Delaware; born in Philadelphia, Pa., in 1747; was graduated from Princeton College in 1771; studied law in Philadelphia; was admitted to the Delaware bar in 1779 and commenced practice in Dover, Del.; moved to Wilmington, Del.; Member of the Continental Congress 1783-1785; appointed attorney general of the State on April 26, 1784, and served until September 26, 1789; appointed a commissioner to the convention held at Annapolis, Md., in September 1786 but did not attend; member of the Federal constitutional convention at Philadelphia in 1787 and signed the Constitution; delegate to the State convention that ratified the Federal Constitution in 1787; member of the State senate in 1788; appointed United States judge for the district of Delaware September 26, 1789, which position he held until his death in Wilmington, Del., March 30, 1812; interment in First Presbyterian Churchyard; reinterment at the Masonic Home of Delaware, on Lancaster Pike, two miles west of Wilmington, Del.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Conrad, Henry C. (Henry Clay). Gunning Bedford, Junior. Read before the Historical Society of Delaware, March 20, 1899. Wilmington: The Historical Society of Delaware, 1900.
Nields, John P. Gunning Bedford, Junior, United States District Judge. [Wilmington, Del.: N.p., 1907].
